Connectivism is a learning theory that incorporates factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society.
Connectivism is a learning theory proposed by George Siemens that emphasizes factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society.

Connectivism is a learning theory proposed by George Siemens that emphasizes factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society, specifically the Internet. One of the main ideas of this theory is that the Internet, being a highly networked area, introduces new connections or learning experiences due to a high degree of interactions. Students go in search of information online as well as share it. This body of shared information becomes a community.
It strikes me that fedwiki is a new way expression of connectivism!

item.text: A page from the PSU Yearbook, La Vie

Connectivism is a learning theory proposed by George Siemens that emphasizes factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society, specifically the Internet. One of the main ideas of this theory is that the Internet, being a highly networked area, introduces new connections or learning experiences due to a high degree of interactions. Students go in search of information online as well as share it. This body of shared information becomes a community.  More about George Siemens here.

Connectivism is a learning theory proposed by George Siemens that emphasizes factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society, specifically the Internet. One of the main ideas of this theory is that the Internet, being a highly networked area, introduces new connections or learning experiences due to a high degree of interactions. Students go in search of information online as well as share it. This body of shared information becomes a community.  More about George Siemens [here http://www.elearnspace.org/blog/about/].

Connectivism is a learning theory proposed by George Siemens that emphasizes factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society, specifically the Internet. One of the main ideas of this theory is that the Internet, being a highly networked area, introduces new connections or learning experiences due to a high degree of interactions. Students go in search of information online as well as share it. This body of shared information becomes a community.  More about George Siemens [http://www.elearnspace.org/blog/about/ here].

item.text: Dave Cormier pushes connectivism to new extremes with his [[rhizomatic learning]]. The core idea of this approach (he does not like calling it a theory) is that the community is the curriculum.

Dave Cormier pushes connectivism to new extremes with his [[rhizomatic learning]]. The core idea of this approach (he does not like calling it a theory) is that the community is the curriculum. Here's a shameless piece of self-promotion ;) [http://www.beds.ac.uk/jpd/volume-4-issue-3/key-pedagogic-thinkers-maha-bali html]
It strikes [[Emily Rimland]]that fedwiki is a new way expression of connectivism!
It strikes [[Emily Rimland]] that fedwiki is a new way expression of connectivism!
It strikes [[Emily Rimland]] that fedwiki is a new expression of connectivism

Dave Cormier pushes connectivism, which he finds too tidy, to new extremes with his [[rhizomatic learning]]. The core idea of this approach (he does not like calling it a theory) is that the community is the curriculum. Here's a shameless piece of self-promotion ;) [http://www.beds.ac.uk/jpd/volume-4-issue-3/key-pedagogic-thinkers-maha-bali html]
It strikes [[Emily Rimland]] that fedwiki is a new expression of connectivism.

Part of what Downes and Siemens introduce in their treatment of Connectivism is that students leave an educational experience not just with understanding, but with a richer network of people, ideas, and resources that allows them to generate new understandings more easily. In this way Fedwiki Happenings are COnnectivist, and Federated Wiki could be seen as a core technology in one's [[Personal Learning Environment]].

This pattern is seen in Federated Wiki most prominently as students move to thier second or third fedwiki experience and find that key concepts, pages, and people from previous experiences become building blocks for new ones.

This pattern is seen in Federated Wiki most prominently as students move to thier second or third fedwiki experience and find that key concepts, pages, and people from previous experiences become building blocks for new ones. The video below shows such an example.

[[Sensemaking]] is one of the learning processes associated with Connectivism.

story.text: Connectivism is a learning theory proposed by George Siemens that emphasizes factors of the digital age in particular the idea of a networked society, specifically the Internet. One of the main ideas of this theory is that the Internet, being a highly networked area, introduces new connections or learning experiences due to a high degree of interactions. Students go in search of information online as well as share it. This body of shared information becomes a community.  More about George Siemens [http://www.elearnspace.org/blog/about/ here].
It strikes [[Emily Rimland]] that fedwiki is a new expression of connectivism.

Part of what Downes and Siemens introduce in their treatment of Connectivism is that students leave an educational experience not just with understanding, but with a richer network of people, ideas, and resources that allows them to generate new understandings more easily. In this way Fedwiki Happenings are COnnectivist, and Federated Wiki could be seen as a core technology in one's [[Personal Learning Environment]].

This pattern is seen in Federated Wiki most prominently as students move to thier second or third fedwiki experience and find that key concepts, pages, and people from previous experiences become building blocks for new ones. The video below shows such an example.
[[Sensemaking]] is one of the learning processes associated with Connectivism.

Dave Cormier pushes connectivism, which he finds too tidy, to new extremes with his [[rhizomatic learning]]. The core idea of this approach (he does not like calling it a theory) is that the community is the curriculum. Here's a shameless piece of self-promotion ;) [http://www.beds.ac.uk/jpd/volume-4-issue-3/key-pedagogic-thinkers-maha-bali html]
